review_title: Toxic leadership culture at Global Support Office compromises the global mission
pros:
The mission – there are few (if any) more rewarding and compelling causes within the charity/NGO sector to work for.

Teams on the ground – the scale of the services being delivered and the bravery that clinical team members display in doing so is unrivalled. They are a credit to the organisation.

Middle management and below at the Global Support Office – the commitment, skills and integrity of those below senior management is what has kept donor relationships and finances in good health, and is not a reflection of how poorly the organisation is led.
cons:
CEO is openly aggressive, rude and disrespectful – meetings where they are present are simply a ‘wait and see what they criticise or decide’ instead of being a genuine discussion, and they claim to have an ‘open door’ policy but are so unapproachable that this is fanciful. The recently launched strategy was stifled by their lack of vision and unwillingness to allow the project team to take the lead.

Delegation of decision making is almost non-existent – middle management has little agency, and often a game of Executive Team ‘Top Trumps’ takes place to resolve disputes. An overwhelming lack of trust holds the organisation back and prevents country programmes from reaching their potential.

Leadership compensation – the financial bonuses earned by Executive Team members are excessive and in no way reflect their input into results; as such, decisions on resource allocation are often made with short-term bonus targets in mind. In addition, the CEO and another Executive Team member were recruited for their commercial acumen but this has translated to almost zero impact in country programmes over the past seven years.

Regular restructures that are handled unprofessionally – numerous restructures took place during my time at the organisation, and each one was dealt with poorly. Their acceptance by team members were negatively impacted by an overtly stubborn lack of information sharing and consultation, and have largely come across as ideological swings of the axe to remove people whose faces don’t fit anymore.

review_title: Great atmosphere and doing important work
job_title: Client Services Advisor in Bristol, England
pros: I really loved my time at Marie Stopes. I met many people who had been there upwards of ten years, as they loved working for the company so much. Although I left after less than a year, this was not due to company-related issues. The work Marie Stopes does is really important, and those who work there are passionate about the cause.  The ultimate pros for me were great colleagues, who were like family, thorough and supportive training, and going in to work every day knowing that I was doing some good in the world.
cons:
The Marie Stopes Call Centre is open 24/7, so hours can be quite variable. This is not necessarily a con - some staff found the flexibility a good thing - and some negotiated regular 9-5 type contracts - but this is something to be aware of, and prepared for before starting.

Call times - Staff on the phones are beginning to be monitored quite strictly for call times, to make sure you are processing your calls as efficiently as possible. They provide a lot of training for this, and if you are struggling with your targets, they will help you. However, it is an added pressure.

review_title: The misalignment between global leadership/board and MSI's mission is a travesty.
pros: The mission of MSI is vital.  The country programs and teams are, in the main, exceptional.  There are many, many gifted and committed people working the support offices to support to vital work MSI provides.
cons: The CEO is a total misfit with this organisation and I would be surprised if he could provide adequate leadership in any organisation.  I was a senior manager with MSI for 5 years and like many of my gifted and hard-working contemporaries, I made the difficult decision to leave because of his overall lack of leadership ability.  He spends an inordinate amount of time and energy managing up to the Board.  He was hired to ensure MSI can be sustainable but he discourages risk and innovation, the very building blocks of MSI.  He has a most unfortunate disposition, with a tendency to blame, intimidate, name and shame and therefore, many team members in the organisation are completely demoralised and uninspired.  I have never encountered a CEO who is so unaccountable.  If it wasn't for the mission, I think the unacceptable turnover of staff would be far worse than it has been since he started. It's just not right.

review_title: White-centric environment in HQ; Lacking seriously in diversity, equity and inclusion
pros: Seriously dedicated people. I have never worked with a more passionate group of people. However, the White Savior complex that exists at MSI detracts from this passion.
cons:
For an organization working to improve the lives of people in poor-resource settings, you would think more would be done to make the staff body in HQ look a bit more like the people they serve and to enshrine the principles of diversity, equity and inclusion in the staff and operations. This is far from the case. In fact, racism and racist attitudes exist strongly. I have seen non-White employees mistreated and scrutinized unfairly. There is also a disgusting culture of "we are here to help them". This White savior complex has no place in development. 

Another thing I took a big issue with is the London HQ office building. It is woefully outdated and too small- insufficient and inadequate work spaces and meeting rooms; toilets that lack proper heating, smelly basement meeting rooms, etc.

review_title: Awesome mission, not great people management
pros:
Incredible mission

Bright, dedicated colleagues, especially those working in the field who are often very courageous

Systems have improved a lot in the last few years

Pay is good for the sector
cons:
Key strategic areas lack coherent strategy or expertise and MSI is losing technical thought leadership in the sector. 

Artificial pressure to keep support office costs low gets in the way of teams being able to spend and deliver against donor contracts. 

While country offices vary a lot, in the UK international side people are not made to feel valued - in fact, feel expendable. This is a culture led from the very top and has caused a lot of people to leave before they should have done. 

Lack of transparency over how jobs are created, promotions given and salary increases  happen  - this causes stress, frustration and unnecessary competition between staff members. Many people feel there's favouritism.

Pay differential for senior management is excessive, esp CEO.

review_title: An amazing global mission that will make you proud to go to work
job_title: Global Digital Lead in London, England
pros: This was one of the hardest jobs I've ever had to leave. MSI is full of dedicated and talented people, and the mission is so fantastic it will spur you to get out of bed on even the most difficult of days. Personally, I always found senior management and my immediate superiors to be heavily invested in my work, respectful of my opinions, and to have a lot of faith in me and my expertise. I was largely left to lead on things without any micro-management, which I found to be very motivating, and I was championed and challenged at the highest levels which was fantastic for my career development.
cons: There is an emphasis on keeping teams 'lean' (particularly in the London office) which is quite one-size-fits-all, and often isn't grounded in a thorough understanding of what resource is actually needed to perform certain tasks. As such this meant that my role/area was just one of many that was chronically understaffed and under-resourced. As a result many people are overworked and under huge amounts of pressure to deliver. My role for example should have been performed by a team of at least 2-3 people and simple wasn't sustainable long term. On a personal note it was hugely disappointing that I never got to visit a country programme in almost 3 years of service - and I did end up feeling quite distanced from the mission in the end.
